title: Nitrofurantoin Macrocrystal Oral: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for nitrofurantoin macrocrystal oral on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) is used to treat or prevent certain [urinary tract infections](https://www.webmd.com/women/your-guide-urinary-tract-infections).This medication is an antibiotic that works by stopping the growth of bacteria. It will not work for [viral infections](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/bacterial-and-viral-infections) (such as [common cold](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/cold-or-flu-quiz), [flu](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/cold-or-flu-quiz)). Unnecessary use or overuse of any antibiotic can lead to its decreased effectiveness. [Nitrofurantoin](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-5183/nitrofurantoin+macrocrystal+oral/details) should not be used by children less than one month of age due to the risk of a certain [blood](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood) problem ( [hemolytic anemia](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/anemia-hemolytic-cold-antibody)). How to use Nitrofurantoin Take this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth) with food or milk as directed by your doctor. This medication is usually taken four times daily to treat an infection or once daily at [bedtime](https://www.webmd.com/parenting/childs-bedtime) to prevent infections. Swallow the medication whole. Avoid using [magnesium](https://www.webmd.com/diet/supplement-guide-magnesium) trisilicate-containing antacids while taking this medication. Magnesium trisilicate-containing antacids bind with [nitrofurantoin](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-5183/nitrofurantoin+macrocrystal+oral/details), preventing its full absorption. Dosage and duration is based on your medical condition and response to therapy. For children, the dosage is also based on [body weight](https://www.webmd.com/diet/tc/healthy-weight-what-is-a-healthy-weight). For the best effect, take this antibiotic at evenly spaced times. To help you remember, take this medication at the same time(s) every day. When taking this medication to prevent infection, take it exactly as directed by your doctor. Do not skip doses or stop taking it without your doctor's approval. Inform your doctor if you notice signs of a new [urinary tract infection](https://www.webmd.com/women/your-guide-urinary-tract-infections) (such as pain while you are urinating). If you are taking this medication to treat an infection, continue to take this medication until the full-prescribed amount is finished, even if symptoms disappear after a few days. Stopping the medication too early may allow bacteria to continue to grow, which may result in a relapse of the infection. Inform your doctor if your condition lasts or gets worse. Side Effects [Nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), [vomiting](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), loss of appetite, or [headache](https://www.webmd.com/migraines-headaches/migraines-headaches-basics) may occur. Take this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) with food to help minimize nausea. If any of these effects last or get worse, notify your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) promptly. This medication may cause your urine to turn dark yellow or brown in color. This effect is harmless and will disappear when the medication is stopped. Remember that this medication has been prescribed because your doctor has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. This medication may rarely cause very serious (possibly fatal) [lung problems](https://www.webmd.com/lung/ss/slideshow-common-lung-problems). [Lung](https://www.webmd.com/lung/picture-of-the-lungs) problems may occur within the first month of treatment or after long-term use of [nitrofurantoin](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-5183/nitrofurantoin+macrocrystal+oral/details) (generally for 6 months or longer). Get medical help right away if you develop symptoms of [lung](https://www.webmd.com/lung/rm-quiz-lungs-quiz) problems, including: [cough](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/overview) your doctor right away if you have any serious side effects, including: headache that is severe or doesn't go away, new signs of infection (such as [sore throat](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/understanding-sore-throat-basics) that doesn't go away, fever), easy bruising/bleeding, mental/mood changes, [vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/vision-basics) changes. This drug may rarely cause serious (possibly fatal) [liver disease](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/liver-and-hepatic-diseases), [blood](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood) or nerve problems. Tell your doctor right away if you notice any of the following serious side effects: nausea/vomiting that doesn't arms/legs, muscle [weakness](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/tc/weakness-and-fatigue-topic-overview). This medication may rarely cause a severe intestinal condition due to a bacteria called C. difficile. This condition may occur during treatment or weeks to months after treatment has stopped. Tell your doctor right away if you develop: [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea) that doesn't stop, abdominal or [stomach pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/abdominal-pain-causes-treatments)/cramping, blood/ [mucus](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/features/the-truth-about-mucus) in your stool. If you have these symptoms, do not use anti- [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/diarrhea-10/slideshow-foods-to-avoid) or [opioid](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/narcotic-pain-medications) products because they may make symptoms worse. Use of this medication for prolonged or repeated periods may result in oral [thrush](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/what-is-thrush) or a new [vaginal yeast infection](https://www.webmd.com/women/understanding-vaginal-yeast-infection-basics) (such as oral or vaginal [fungal infection](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/fungal-infections-skin)). Contact your doctor if you notice white patches in your [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth), a change in [vaginal discharge](https://www.webmd.com/women/vaginal-discharge-whats-abnormal), or other new symptoms. A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your doctor or pharmacist. In the US - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to FDA at 1-800-FDA-1088 or at www.fda.gov/medwatch. In Canada - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to Health Canada at 1-866-234-2345. Precautions Before taking [nitrofurantoin](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-5183/nitrofurantoin+macrocrystal+oral/details), tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) if you are allergic to it; or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients, which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your pharmacist for more details. Before using this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), tell your doctor or pharmacist your medical [liver problems](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/liver-and-hepatic-diseases) caused in the past), a certain genetic condition (G-6-PD deficiency), certain [blood disorders](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/blood-disorder-types-and-treatment) (such mineral imbalance, vitamin B deficiency. Nitrofurantoin may cause live bacterial [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) (such as [typhoid](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/typhoid) [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation)) to not work well. Tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional that you are using nitrofurantoin before having any [immunizations](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation)/ [vaccinations](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation). Older adults may be at a greater risk for side effects while using this drug, especially nerve, [liver](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-liver) or [lung problems](https://www.webmd.com/lung/ss/slideshow-common-lung-problems). During pregnancy, this medication should be used only when clearly needed. This medication should not be used if you are near or at the time of delivery (weeks 38-42 of pregnancy) due to possible harm to the [newborn](https://www.webmd.com/parenting/baby/ss/slideshow-baby-milestones-first-year), such as a certain [blood](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood) problem ( [hemolytic anemia](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/anemia-hemolytic-cold-antibody)). Discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. This medication passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk and may have undesirable effects on nursing infants less than one month old and infants with a certain genetic condition (G-6-PD deficiency). Consult your doctor before breast-feeding. Interactions See also the How to Use section. [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your doctor and [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. A product that may interact with this drug is: [sulfinpyrazone](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-8712/sulfinpyrazone+oral/details). This [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) may interfere with certain lab tests (such as certain urine [glucose](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/glucose-diabetes) tests), possibly causing false test results. Make sure lab personnel and all your doctors know you use this drug. Overdose If someone has overdosed and has serious symptoms such as passing out or [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments), call 911. Otherwise, call a poison control center right away. US residents can call their local poison control center at 1-800-222-1222. Canada residents can call a provincial poison control center. Do not share this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) with others. This medication has been prescribed for your current condition only. Do not use it later for another infection unless your doctor tells you to. Lab and/or medical tests (such as complete [blood](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood) counts, tests for [kidney](https://www.webmd.com/kidney-stones/picture-of-the-kidneys) and [liver function](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/liver-function-test-lft), urine cultures) should be done while you are taking this medication. Keep all medical and lab appointments. Consult your doctor for more details. If you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. If it is near the time of the next dose, skip the missed dose. Take your next dose at the regular time. Do not double the dose to catch up. Store at room temperature away from light and moisture. Do not store in the bathroom. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company.
